children.name: ignorant
children.definition: sb who is ignorant does not know facts or information that they should know: không biết gì
examples: ignorance[U] C2 when sb does not know facts or information that they should know
I haven’t read your latest book, so I hope you’ll forgive my ignorance.
ignorance of/ about
He showed complete ignorance of the most basic historical facts.
Public ignoranceaboutthe disease is still a cause for concern.
in ignorance
I would have remained in ignorance if Shaun hadn’t mentioned it.
Patients, it is claimed, were kept/leftinignoranceofwhat was wrong with them

children.name: an ignorant and uneducated man
examples: I didn’t like to ask him to explain more clearly because I didn’t want to appear ignorant.

children.name: ignorant of
examples: Political historians are often rather ignorant of economics.
There are still doctors who are ignorant of patients’ rights, or who try to deny them.

children.name: ignorant about
examples: I’m very ignorant about politics.

children.name: blissfully ignorant
examples: Many people remainblissfully ignorantabout the dangers of too much sun(= happy because they do not know about the dangers ).
We remainedblissfullyignorantofthe troubles that lay ahead.

children.name: uninformed
children.definition: people or opinions that are uninformed show a lack of knowledge and information about the subject that they are discussing: không biết, không thông tin, không hiểu biết
examples: ▪ Careless or uninformed decisions during these huge storms can lead to loss of life and property.

children.name: uninformed about
examples: ▪ The Vice-President gave the impression of being remarkably uninformed about South American affairs.

children.name: ill-informed
children.definition: not knowing much about sth or making mistakes about it because you have been given incorrect or not enough information: thiếu hiểu biết, kém hiểu biết
examples: ▪ He’s either a liar or he’s incredibly ill-informed.
▪ Writers such as Oscar Wilde were the target of ill-informed and often hostile criticism simply because they were gay.

children.name: ill-informed about
examples: ▪ For someone who wants to be a journalist, she’s remarkably ill-informed about current affairs.

children.name: layman
children.definition: /lay person sb who has no special knowledge about a subject such as science or medicine, as opposed to people who have special knowledge or training: người không chuyên, tay không chuyên
examples: Professor Hawking’s book is intended for the lay person who has an interest in the field of nuclear physics and astronomy.

children.name: in layman’s termsusing words a layman can understand theo cách nói phổ thông
examples: Many superb doctors are incapable of communicating in layman’s terms.

children.name: If you don’t understand what the doctor says, ask to have it explainedin layman’s terms
to not know a fact or piece of info
not know
children.definition: không biết

children.name: ▪ ‘What time’s the next train to Paris?’ ‘I’m sorry, I don’t know.’
examples: ▪ I wish I could tell you the name of the restaurant but I honestly don’t know it.

children.name: not know (that)
examples: ▪ My mother never knew that they’d called the police out that night.

children.name: not know anything about
examples: ▪ These days, record companies are usually owned by people who don’t know anything about music.

children.name: not know how/what/why etc
examples: ▪ I don’t know why it is so difficult to explain the concept to people.
▪ No one knows if there really is a Loch Ness monster, or if it’s just a myth.

children.name: have no idea
children.definition: /not have a clueB2  especially spoken say this when you know nothing at all about the answer to a question, so that you cannot even guess what it might be: không biết gì

children.name: ▪ ‘How much is this painting worth?’ ‘I’m sorry, I’ve no idea.’
examples: ▪ When I asked where Louise had gone, he said he didn’t have a clue.

children.name: have no idea/not have a clue what/how/who etc
examples: ▪ That guy obviously doesn’t have a clue how to put a Web page together.
▪ I fell asleep half way through the film, and I have absolutely no idea how it ended.

children.name: not have the faintest/slightest/foggiest idea/ not have the least idea UK
children.definition: say this when you want to say very strongly that you know nothing at all: không biết một chút gì về
examples: ▪ ‘Do you know where he was going after he left here?’ ‘I don’t have the slightest idea.’
not have the faintest/slightest/foggiest idea what/how/where etc
▪ I don’t have the faintest idea what you’re talking about -- can you explain please?
▪ Nobody at that time had the slightest idea about how caffeine affected the body.
not have the faintest/slightest/foggiest idea about
▪ They didn’t have the least idea about how to put up a tent.

children.name: (it) beats me
children.definition: say this when you do not know and cannot understand why sth happens: tôi chịu
examples: ▪ ‘What I can’t understand is why they make you wait three months just to give you a stamp on your passport.’ ‘Beats me too.’
(it) beats me how/why etc
▪ It beats me how these kids can afford to spend so much money on clothes and CDs.

children.name: don't ask me
children.definition: don’t ask me/ how should I know? spoken informal say this when it is impossible for you to know the answer to a question, especially when you are annoyed or surprised that someone has asked you: đừng hỏi tôi
examples: ‘Why is Sharon in such a bad mood?’ ‘How should I know - she never tells me anything.’
‘We figured we could pay about $200 a week, right?’ ‘Don’t ask me! I wasn’t in on the conversation.’
Don't ask me where you've left your glasses!

children.name: I give up
children.definition: say this when you do not know the answer to a difficult question or a joke, and you want someone to tell you: tôi bỏ cuộc
examples: ▪ ‘Guess who’s coming to dinner tonight?’ ‘I give up. Tell me.’
▪ ‘Why did the chicken cross the road?’ ‘I give up, why did the chicken cross the road?’

children.name: to not know a place, film or book etc
unfamiliar
children.definition: be  with sth: to know little or nothing about a subject, book, play etc because you have not studied it, read it, or seen it: xa lạ với
examples: We were unfamiliar with the neighbourhood.
Many older people are unfamiliar with computers.

children.name: It is difficult for anyone unfamiliar with astronomy to grasp the concept of the Black Hole
not know
children.definition: không biết

children.name: not familiar
children.definition: not be familiar with to know little or nothing about a subject, book, play etc because you have not studied it, read it, or seen it: xa lạ với
examples: I’m afraid I’m not familiar with Professor Vaughan’s work.
For those of you who may not be familiar with the play I’ll give a brief summary of the plot.

children.name: to not know anything about a subject
not know anything
children.definition: /know nothing  không biết gì
examples: ▪ Don’t ask me. I know nothing at all about fixing cars.
▪ No one else at school knew anything about jazz.

children.name: know nothing offormal không biết gì về
examples: ▪ When he arrived in Venice he knew almost nothing of its history or culture.

children.name: have no idea
children.definition: /not have a clue  informal to know nothing at all about how to do something: không biết chút gì, không một chút manh mối
examples: ▪ I’m amazed how he puts all the bits of the computer back together. I wouldn’t have a clue.

children.name: have no idea/not have a clue about không một chút manh mối gì vì
examples: ▪ After nine years of marriage, he still didn’t have a clue about what she really wanted.

children.name: have no idea/not have a clue how/what/where etc không một chút manh mối thế nào, cái gì, ở đâu
examples: ▪ It became clear that the sales people didn’t have any idea how to sell the new products.

children.name: be a closed book
children.definition: a subject that is a closed book to someone is one that they know nothing about, and that they believe they will never understand: hoàn toàn không biết gì
examples: ▪ For many people, science is something of a closed book.

children.name: to not know the most recent info about sth
be out of touch
children.definition: sb who is out of touch with sth used to know about it but does not now know the most recent information about it, because they have not read about it or been involved in it for a long time: không có tin tức
examples: ▪ I don’t know what kind of music kids listen to these days -- I’m really out of touch.

children.name: be out of touch with
examples: ▪ The press accused MacGregor of being out of touch with the campaign he was supposed to be running.

children.name: lose touch
children.definition: if you lose touch with a situation or a subject, you no longer know the latest information about it and are unable to understand what is happening in it:
examples: ▪ I must do some teaching again -- I’m worried about losing touch.

children.name: lose touch with
examples: ▪ The French President has lost touch with the reality of the political situation in France.
▪ When you’re living abroad, it’s easy to lose touch with what’s going on back home.

children.name: lose track of
children.definition: if you lose track of sb/sth, you no longer know where they are or what has happened to them: không nắm
examples: ▪ I had the file on my desk a minute ago, but I seem to have lost track of it.
▪ After the war they lost track of each other.
▪ They fed us every twelve hours, but when you can’t see the sun, you lose track of time.

children.name: not be up on
children.definition: if you are not up on the latest fashions, music, or news, you do not know about them: không đuổi kịp, không theo kịp
examples: ▪ I spend most of my time in the woods of Wyoming these days, so I’m not really up on all the latest fashions and movies.
▪ My dad’s not really up on what kids think these days.

children.name: to not know about sth that other people know
be in the dark
children.definition: if you are in the dark about sth, especially sth important, you have not been told about it because other people want to keep it secret:
examples: ▪ We have no idea why he’s been arrested. We’re still completely in the dark.

children.name: be in the dark about
examples: ▪ Most board members were kept in the dark about this important financial information.
▪ We’re being kept in the dark about the dangers of food additives by the big food manufacturers.

children.name: not be in on
children.definition: if you are not in on a secret plan, you have not been told about it and are not involved in it:
examples: ▪ They weren’t in on the robbery -- only me and my brother knew about it.

children.name: ways of saying that no one knows sth
who knows
children.definition: /who can sayai mà biết được chứ
examples: Maybe the world will end tomorrow. Who can say?
He might come back and say he still loves me, who knows? Who cares?
who knows?[] spoken say this when you think it is impossible for anyone to know the answer to a question: ai mà biết, ai biết được
The world might end tomorrow. Who knows?

children.name: who knows/who can say what/where/why etc
examples: Who knows whether Mimi ever made it to Paris.
The world might end tomorrow. Who knows?

children.name: God knows
children.definition: /heaven knows spoken say this when you mean that it is impossible to know sth: có trời mới biết
examples: ▪ ‘Where’d she go?’ ‘God knows.’
God knows/heaven knows what/who/why etc
▪ I’ve just missed my train, so God knows what time I’ll get home now.
▪ Heaven knows why she feels she can’t trust her own parents.

children.name: it’s anybody’s guess
children.definition: say this when neither you, nor anyone else knows the answer to a question or the truth about sth, and any answer could be correct: chỉ là suy đoán của mỗi người
examples: ▪ How he’d lived through it all is anybody’s guess.

children.name: it’s anybody’s guess who/what/why etc
examples: ▪ It’s anybody’s guess who will come out on top when the winners are announced at the Grammy Awards this year.

children.name: there’s no knowing
children.definition: there’s no telling/knowing spoken say this when it is impossible to know what will happen, especially when you are worried that something bad might happen: chả thể nào biết

children.name: there’s no telling/knowing who/what/why
examples: ▪ ‘He’s a desperate man. There’s no telling what he’ll do next,’ said Holmes.
▪ There was no knowing when the flood waters might recede with so much rain in the forecast.

children.name: your guess is as good as mine
children.definition: say this when sb asks you a question and you do not know the answer, so that they are just as likely to guess the right answer as you are: tôi không biết
examples: ‘Who do you think will win the World Cup?’ ‘Your guess is as good as mine.’
